page.paragraph: Now listen to a conversation between two students.
Hey, Pam, you don't look too happy. What's the matter?
It's the assignment we just got back in management class. I didn't do very well on it.
Did you work very hard on it?
I spent a whole lot of time on it. I really worked hard. I went to the library and researched the issue, and I spent hours writing the paper.
Do you understand why the grade was so low? Maybe I can help.
Did you do well on the assignment?
Yes, I did.
Then I think you can help. Do you have any ideas?
A couple, based on what you just said. First of all, you said you went to the library and researched the theory we were supposed to write about.
Yes, I did. I researched it thoroughly.
Well, the assignment was to write your opinion of the theory. The professor said very specifically that she wanted our thoughts on it. Did you give your opinion on the theory in your paper?
Well, first I wrote about the history of the theory, from all my research, and then later in the paper I talked about what the theory means.
Not your opinion about it?
No, not exactly….
Well, the professor wanted our opinion….
I see that now. That was my problem, I'm sure.
Just a minute. One more thing. When you said "later in the paper," what did you mean? I mean, how long was your paper?
Just eight pages.
Just eight pages? The professor said she wanted answers that are succinct and to the point. She really stressed that.
So you think she didn't appreciate the eight-page paper?
Not exactly.
By the way, how long was your paper, the one you got a high grade on?
Under two pages.
Under two pages? And you got a high grade? Oh, my!
